Source: Understanding Points of Correspondence between Sentences for Abstractive Summarization, paper:https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.05621
Definition: You will be given three sentences. Read them, then identify a noun phrase (person, place, or thing) or event that is shared between all three sentences. As the output, write the span of the text corresponding to that phrase in each sentence.

Positive Examples.input: sentence 1: Four employees of the store have been arrested , but its manager -- herself a woman -- was still at large Saturday , said Goa police superintendent Kartik Kashyap . sentence 2: If convicted , they could spend up to three years in jail , Kashyap said . sentence 3: The four store workers arrested could spend 3 years each in prison if convicted .
Positive Examples.output: sentence 1: Four employees of the store sentence 2: they sentence 3: The four store workers
Positive Examples.explanation: All three mentioned parts refer to the same entity, the four eployees. "Of the store" in first sentence must be included, since it is part of the same noun phrase describing the employees.

Positive Examples.input: sentence 1: Stewart said that she and her husband , Joseph Naaman , booked Felix on their Etihad Airways flight from the United Arab Emirates to New York 's John F . Kennedy International Airport on April 1 . sentence 2: The couple said they spent $ 1,200 to ship Felix on the 14-hour flight . sentence 3: Couple spends $ 1,200 to ship their cat , Felix , on a flight from the United Arab Emirates .
Positive Examples.output: sentence 1: their Etihad Airways flight from the United Arab Emirates to New York 's John F . Kennedy International Airport sentence 2: the 14-hour flight sentence 3: a flight from the United Arab Emirates
Positive Examples.explanation: All the words that are part of the phrase should be mentioned. In this case, mentioning only the "Etihad Airways flight" was not enough.

Positive Examples.input: sentence 1: But an Arizona official told CNN Bates never trained with the agency . sentence 2:  He did n't come to Arizona ,  the official from the Maricopa County Sheriff 's Office said ,  and he certainly did n't train with us .  sentence 3: Maricopa County Sheriff 's Office in Arizona says Robert Bates never trained with them .
Positive Examples.output: sentence 1: never trained sentence 2: did n't train sentence 3: never trained
Positive Examples.explanation: This is an example where the point of correspondence between three sentences is an event, described by verbs.

Negative Examples.input: sentence 1: Stewart said that she and her husband , Joseph Naaman , booked Felix on their Etihad Airways flight from the United Arab Emirates to New York 's John F . Kennedy International Airport on April 1 . sentence 2: The couple said they spent $ 1,200 to ship Felix on the 14-hour flight . sentence 3: Couple spends $ 1,200 to ship their cat , Felix , on a flight from the United Arab Emirates .
Negative Examples.output: sentence 1: she and her husband sentence 2: couple sentence 3: Couple
Negative Examples.explanation: Mentioning only "she and her husband" in sentence 1 would be incorrect, because "Joseph Naaman" is part of the same noun phrase. Similarly, mentioning only "couple" in sentence 2 would be incorrect; you must mention "the couple."

Negative Examples.input: sentence 1: But an Arizona official told CNN Bates never trained with the agency . sentence 2:  He did n't come to Arizona ,  the official from the Maricopa County Sheriff 's Office said ,  and he certainly did n't train with us .  sentence 3: Maricopa County Sheriff 's Office in Arizona says Robert Bates never trained with them .
Negative Examples.output: sentence 1: the agency sentence 3: Maricopa County Sheriff 's Office in Arizona
Negative Examples.explanation: The two noun phrases given in this example are correct, but there's no noun phrase from sentence 2. You should include all three sentences in your response.
